text:
So, this is a dinosaur bone
from our collection,

and it shows
a sign of a tumour here.

So, a lot of people think
that cancer is a modern disease.

But we know from the fossil record
from 200 million years ago

that dinosaurs were affected
by cancer, too.

The difference between dinosaurs
of the past
and us living in our world today
is that there are different factors

that can contribute
and lead to cancer.

Around four in ten cancers
could be prevented

through things that
we can change ourselves,

such as keeping a healthy weight,
being more active.
But there are some things that we do

that can increase our risk
of cancer,

and we need to know what those are
so that we can reduce our risk

and live as healthy a life
as possible.

Smoking is the biggest preventable
cause of cancer in the UK.
Smoking causes 15 types of cancer,
not just lung cancer,

Oesophageal cancer,
cervical cancer,
kidney cancer, bladder cancer
and bowel cancer,
and many, many more.

And it's not just burning tobacco,
lighting cigarettes, that does it.

Things like shisha
can cause cancers,
as can smokeless tobacco, too.
I often get asked about vaping

and whether it's more harmful
than cigarettes.

The field or the area of vaping
hasn't been well studied.

We haven't been doing this
long enough to really understand.
So for those who are smoking

and using vaping as a transition
out of that,

I hope that that continues
to work for you.

Um, but for those who have
considered picking up vaping,

I would highly suggest
that you don't.
We just don't know the impact.

Stopping smoking by far is the best
thing you can do for your health.
The human papillomavirus, or HPV,
is a common virus.

And actually eight out of ten of us
will be infected
with this virus at some time.

Most of the time, HPV is symptomless
and has no issues.

We can actually clear this virus
ourselves most of the time,

but in those
that are unable to clear it,

it can cause cell changes,
which can lead to abnormal cells,

which can then lead on
to cervical cancer.

It wasn't really in public awareness
until personalities like Jade Goody

talked about
her cervical cancer struggle.

But understanding HPV, preventing
HPV and screening for HPV

are one of the main important things
we can do

to reduce the risk of cervical
cancer and other cancers, too.

But the good news is
that the HPV vaccination
that we now give to girls and boys

is helping to stop
the spread of the infection.

Did you know that
one in ten cases of lung cancer
are caused by air pollution?

Obviously, the majority of them
come from smoking,

which is sort of very direct air
pollution directly into your lungs.

But the way it works is
tiny molecules in the air

floating around, pollutants from
things like cars, from factories

and from other sources,
can get into the lungs.
They can irritate them

and they wake up
some sleeping damaged cells there,

which can go on
to become lung cancer.

Levels of air pollution
are higher in towns and in cities,

but we also know that smoke indoors
from wood fires

or passive smoking can also increase
your risk of getting lung cancer.

It's not easy to move away
from where you live

in order to reduce your risk
of air pollution,
and therefore your risk of cancer.

So what we need is we need lots of
action to make the world we live in
a much greener, cleaner place.

Sometimes this sort of thing
can sound scary.

You know, we live in a world where
there's lots of things around us
that can potentially cause us harm.

However, there's an awful lot
we can do to prevent more cancers.

So the future of cancer research
is really bright,

and it's really exciting
that people are living longer

and living healthier,
even post a cancer diagnosis.

There are so many
brilliant research teams in the UK,
around the world,

who are really examining
every aspect of cancer
and how we can tackle it,

whether it's through
diagnosing it better,

through imaging technologies
or blood tests

and finding new treatments
that, you know,

help people live
better-quality lives
whilst being treated for cancer.

And, yes, of course,
there are some things

that can increase your risk
of getting cancer.

But the important thing is,
if you know about these risks,

you can take steps to try
and reduce your risk in life

and you can try and live
as healthier life as possible.
There's no miracle cure for cancer,

but if you do notice anything
that's wrong with you,

go to the doctor's,
and the sooner you're spotted,
the sooner you can be treated

and the sooner
you can just have a healthy life.
